A huge thank you to @lungdiagnosis for tonight's fantastic lecture and Q&A session on the role of #imaging in the fight against #COVID19. 

His session will be available to watch again soon, meanwhile, you can catch up on previous #RCRTalks here: https://t.co/hGttp0CkAC

A further #RCRTalks viewer asked Dr Hare if SARS infection could cause lung #cancer. 

He explained that while severe lung scarring can be a precursor to cancer, there has been no direct causal link seen between SARS/#coronavirus and lung cancer.

Asked about how #COVID19 might be causing abdominal symptoms, Dr Hare said #coronavirus could be causing micro- clots in blood vessels in the abdomen, causing pain.
#RCRTalks

"What you see on scans are white, wispy streaks," Dr Hare explained. "The lung has become distorted and squashed in those areas."

However, he added that these "squashed" lung problems should decrease, as #COVID19 progression is being halted sooner now with steroid treatment.
One #RCRTalks viewer asked Dr Hare about what was happening with #LongCovid patients who, conversely, are showing lung damage on #imaging later on...

He added: "I myself felt unwell for weeks and weeks after having #COVID19 and had a clear chest X-ray". 

At the same time, other patients are showing lung scarring 6 months after their initial #coronavirus infection.

Commenting on how patients suffering #LongCovid can have normal follow-up scans, Dr Hare told #RCRTalks delegates it appeared that many patients who had seemingly mild symptoms initially are feeling unwell for longer, with no obvious issues seen via lung #imaging....

Asked about the long-term impact of SARS on patients' lungs, Dr Hare explained that lung scarring had been seen in 20-30% of SARS patients previously, and he expected similar rates to be seen in #COVID19 patients.
#RCRTalks
Dr Hare added that so far during #coronavirus wave 2, the use of steroids for #COVID19 treatment is shortening the illness seen overall: "it's the main change we've seen this time around."

Kicking off the #RCRTalks Q&A, the RCR's @WilliamHRamsden asked Dr Hare how immediately obvious #COVID19 is on #imaging.

.@lungdiagnosis explained that diagnosis via scans tends to be obvious as patients presenting to hospital tend to be suffering severe covid progression...

Dr Hare wrapped up his #RCRTalks session by urging all patients in need to access the #NHS: "we've put an infrastructure in place where we have non-#COVID19 sites and you can rest assured you will be safe when you come to hospital."
#HelpUsHelpYou

While news of advancing #COVID19 vaccines offers hope, Dr Hare urged viewers to remain patient and keep adhering to all the ongoing #coronavirus public health measures, adding "we need to protect lungs".
#RCRTalks

Our understanding of the non-respiratory symptoms and long-term impact of #COVID19 is growing, says Dr Hare, adding that there is also growing concern around long-term lung scarring and the impact of #LongCovid 
#RCRTalks

Dr Hare explained how #radiology teams have adapted practice ‚Äì using one scanner for non-#COVID19 patients and one for those with suspected/confirmed #coronavirus, utilising dedicated covid-secure sites and overnight reporting of possible covid cases. 
#RCRTalks

Dr Hare noted how the #radiology community and @BSTImaging quickly worked to produce resources to help standardise #COVID19 chest X-ray reports, along with an open access database so chest radiologists could share expertise with colleagues across the UK. 
#RCRTalks

Commenting again on the importance of #radiology, Dr Hare stressed: ‚Äúevery single patient was having an #imaging test for their #coronavirus, that is the untold story of the pandemic ‚Äì the oil that was driving the machinery of the hospital was the imaging department.‚Äù
#RCRTalks

Dr Hare showed how life has changed for #imaging teams ‚Äì with full PPE for radiographers and radiologists making work more difficult, and radiographers doing more scanning with portable equipment to help with #COVID19 infection control.
#RCRTalks https://t.co/LbUjDYPNvC

Dr Hare stressed how #imaging has been vital for making a quick #COVID19 diagnosis to help hospital triage, given swabs can take 24-48hrs, with up to 1/3 false negatives.
#RCRTalks

Dr Hare described how the flood of patients during the first wave of #coronavirus meant that the #NHS ‚Äúmetaphorically couldn‚Äôt breathe", adding: ‚Äúordinarily I might see 1 or 2 patients with pneumonia during my normal day‚Ä¶ during the first surge I was seeing 40-50."
#RCRTalks
The swab test on that patient was then repeated, and came back positive for #coronavirus.

Despite a negative #COVID19 swab, the patient clearly had an abnormal chest scan.

Dr Hare immediately told colleagues, ‚Äúignore the swab result, this is #coronavirus‚Äù, urging them to isolate the patient and instigate full infection control measures...
After talking #RCRTalks viewers through how #COVID19 pneumonia affects lung air sacs, Dr Hare described the first #coronavirus patient he saw in March 2020‚Ä¶ https://t.co/GXIuu9VhxM

Dr Hare kicked off his lecture by explaining what the #radiology team does as ‚Äúthe hub of the hospital‚Äù, and the vital role team members play in diagnosing, treating and managing patients. 
#RCRTalks

And concluded by discussing emerging therapies, such as stem cell injections and surgical release, and utilising biomarkers seen on scans, which can highlight stiffness and chemical build-up... With the future of #sportsimaging now moving towards injury prediction and prevention.

Dr Robinson covered emerging interventional radiology procedures for sports injuries, including paratenon distension to break up Achilles‚Äô tendon scar tissue, and fenestration and blood injections to stimulate tissue healing...
He described the multidisciplinary team that supported athletes at the London 2012 Olympics - who benefited from on-site #sportsimaging at the Olympic village, including CT, MRI and ultrasound...

.@philrobmsk walked #RCRTalks delegates through the common forms of sports injuries, with 95% being muscle - rather than bone - related - as a result the most useful and prolific #sportsimaging techniques are now ultrasound and MRI...
He described the multidisciplinary team that supported athletes at the London 2012 Olympics - who benefited from on-site #sportsimaging at the Olympic village, including CT, MRI and ultrasound...

Dr Murray concluded: ‚ÄúThe future for our health is bright, despite negative things in the press - there‚Äôs good stuff in terms of medical improvements and imaging, and opportunities for clinical collaboration.‚Äù
In sports medicine, global learning and connectivity, advances in #sportsimaging, clinical teamwork and patient involvement are all huge benefits of modern medicine advances...
And regular exercise reducing risk of death by 30%... With good diet, taking breaks and teamwork and compassion all easy wins to improve individual and public health...
He urged #RCRTalks delegates to look at ‚Äúeasy health wins‚Äù including getting enough sleep - with the risk of catching a cold 4 times less if you go from 5-8 hours sleep...
.@docandrewmurray enthused about the positive health advances seen in the West in the past 200 years - with life expectancy tripling and massive reductions in infectious diseases.... #RCRTalks
